Hi Barry and Mr. Chen;

Interesting thread.  While there is quite a bit of =
evidence relating to the trade in weapons in the Muromachi period between J=
apan and China, the style of the tsuba you have illustrated is not of a sty=
le from this period of trade, but from a much later period.  There have bee=
n many discussions trying to determine what happened to the thousands of sw=
ords exported to China during this period.  Also the popular opinion is tha=
t these swords were mounted in koshira, so would have had the required tsub=
a and other fittings, at least on a portion of the swords exported even if =
not all.  Seeing as the numbers exported were in the tens of thousands over=
 a long period, it seems reasonable to think there should be a quantity of =
tsuba remaining from these weapons.

Here is a link to a picture of a tsuba=
 that I think was made for this export market in Japan, and it is in the st=
yle and iron of the period used in Japan, it is the second picture from the=
 top.  If you look at the next picture it is of a similar style of tsuba bu=
t the iron is different as is the style of construction and it is from a la=
ter period of production even though of a similar style, and is about 100 y=
ears later in manufacture.  This would cause one to wonder if this trade co=
ntinued though the years but perhaps in smaller quantities.

http://www3.te=
lus.net/sword/sword/index.htm/MyWebs6/tsb1gal.htm

John
